title: Who could be considered the 'Father' of atheism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Religious people have difficulty understanding atheist thinking. This is why they make assumptions that baffle atheists - like assuming atheists are angry with God and that’s why we don’t believe in him. It’s also why those seeking to discredit atheism like to target famous thinkers like Darwin or, more contemporary, Dawkins. In religion, founding figures are important. They are the prophets that guide us. Their message is less important than the messenger - I mean, it’s not like Jesus was telling us anything new with this “be kind to others” stuff, and it’s not like his most vocal supporters pay any attention to his teachings anyway. So naturally the religious assume it’s the same for atheists. We all look up to some great prophet who showed us the light. There is no father of atheism. You aren’t raised to believe in it. You find it for yourself. All those that go before us do is show the way, and they’ve been doing it for thousands of years.

A fella named “Rodney”. He didn’t make that big a deal out of it, so he never got the notoriety he deserved. Rodney also holds the patent on indifference, but missed out on a real cash cow when he failed to get a registered trademark assigned to “Meh”, an exclamation he coined while visiting the Largest Ball of Twine in Minnesota, finding himself underwhelmed by the experience. Note: Next Wednesday is International Rodney Day. It’s traditional to celebrate it with cash offerings. Coincidentally, I’m the accountant for the event. Make your donations via PayPal, payable directly to me. Unless you don’t believe in silly, made up things, in which case, congratulations. You’ve discovered atheism… = = = = = = = = =
